Ottoman Empire

Relevant ages

  • Age of Imperial Zenith

Welcome to our site on the Ottoman Empire, a powerful state that controlled Southeast Europe, Western Asia, and North Africa from the 14th century. Explore the empire's origins, expansion, and cultural impact, from its founding by Osman I to its peak under Suleiman the Magnificent.

Founded around 1299 by Osman I in Anatolia, the Ottoman Empire expanded through conquest, ending the Byzantine Empire with the capture of Constantinople in 1453. Under leaders like Mehmed II and Suleiman the Magnificent, the empire became a global power, controlling vital trade routes and diverse territories. The empire granted autonomy to various religious communities and saw its peak in the 16th and 17th centuries, but later faced internal stagnation and territorial losses. The Ottoman Empire dissolved after World War I, replaced by the Republic of Turkey in 1923.

List of rulers of Ottoman Empire

1603

Beginning of Ottoman-Safavid War

The Ottoman-Safavid War was a series of conflicts between the Ottoman Empire and the Safavid Empire. The Ottomans lost all the lands they had gained under the Treaty of Ferhat Pasha. The war ended with the Treaty of Serav in 1618, which acknowledged the losses suffered by the Ottomans. This conflict highlighted the ongoing struggle between the two empires for control over key territories in the Caucasus and Mesopotamia.

1622

Regicide of Osman II

Osman II was killed on May 20, 1622, by the imperial army, marking a turning point in the nature of the Ottoman Empire. The legally approved regicide of a reigning Ottoman monarch cemented the empire's transformation from a patrimonial empire into one in which power was shared between various loci of authority. Osman II's death was caused by the Janissaries, who revolted against him.

1623

Beginning of Reign of Murad IV

During his brief majority reign, Murad IV (1623–1640) reasserted central authority and recaptured Iraq (1639) from the Safavids. Murad IV managed to restore central authority and military prowess to the Empire. The Treaty of Zuhab of that same year decisively divided the Caucasus and adjacent regions between the two neighboring empires as it had already been defined in the 1555 Peace of Amasya.

1645

Conquest of Crete

From 1645 onward the Ottomans were preoccupied with the difficult conquest of Crete from the Republic of Venice. The island was quickly overrun, but Venetian naval superiority enabled the fortress of Candia (modern Heraklion) to resist for decades. The conquest of Crete was finally completed in 1669 with the fall of Candia.

1656

Köprülü Era

During the Köprülü era (1656–1703), effective control of the Empire was exercised by a sequence of grand viziers from the Köprülü family. The Köprülü Vizierate saw renewed military success with authority restored in Transylvania. The Köprülü family helped regain the expansion into Polish southern Ukraine, with the strongholds of Khotyn, and Kamianets-Podilskyi and the territory of Podolia ceding to Ottoman control in 1676.

1683

Battle of Vienna

This period of renewed assertiveness came to a calamitous end in 1683 when Grand Vizier Kara Mustafa Pasha led a huge army to attempt a second Ottoman siege of Vienna in the Great Turkish War of 1683–1699. The final assault being fatally delayed, the Ottoman forces were swept away by allied Habsburg, German, and Polish forces spearheaded by the Polish king John III Sobieski at the Battle of Vienna. The Ottoman defeat at Vienna marked a turning point in the balance of power in Europe, signaling the beginning of the decline of Ottoman influence in the region.

1699

Treaty of Karlowitz

The alliance of the Holy League pressed home the advantage of the defeat at Vienna, culminating in the Treaty of Karlowitz (26 January 1699), which ended the Great Turkish War. The Ottomans surrendered control of significant territories, many permanently. The Ottomans ceded most of Hungary to Austria in the Treaty of Karlowitz.

1700

Treaty of Constantinople with Russia

On July 3 (14), 1700, in Constantinople, Russia and Turkey concluded a peace treaty resulting from Azov campaigns of Peter I in 1695-1696. The treaty was signed by Russian envoy Yemelyan Ignatievich Ukraintsev and Turkish Grand Vizier Nikolai Mavrokordato. Under the treaty, Russia received Azov along with the adjoining territory and restored fortresses, gaining access to the Azov Sea. The treaty, concluded for 30 years, was observed until November 1710, when Turkey declared war on Russia.
